newsitem.title: USA: US OPTIONS FOCUS/No end seen to market volatility.
newsitem.headline: US OPTIONS FOCUS/No end seen to market volatility.

text.p: Implied volatility in major U.S. stock index options, which typically declines when the indices rally, held firm Thursday in the face of a strong upswing, suggesting investors see no end to the increased level of choppiness, traders said.
By about 1200 CDT/1700 GMT, the bellwether Dow industrial average was ahead 103 points at 7,189.
The average dropped about 140 points Wednesday. It rose 11 points Tuesday after surging 143 on Monday.
The broader S&P 100 index .OEX was up nearly 10 points at 808.86 and the S&P 500 .SPX rose 10 to 825.67.
"Volatility is pretty much holding a steady line even though we've got a good rally going," said an index options trader at the Chicago Mercantile Exchange.
"Hundred-point moves (on the Dow) are expected," he said.
June S&P 500 futures were ahead 12.85 at 830.50, a point off their session peaks.
One firm pegged fair value at 3.45 points premium to cash, with buy programs at 4.50 points premium or wider and sell programs at 2.70 points premium or narrower.

"We've seen buyers on both sides of the market here, so there might be some anticipation of more volatility next week," said Jack Callahan, an independent market maker in the OEX, noting that May options expire next week.
"On the other hand, expirations have been the tamest weeks of the (option) cycle," he added.
He said some investors may be starting to unwind positions ahead of next week's expiration.
Put buying and call selling were heavy off the opening, but call buyers quickly emerged as the market began to run higher, Callahan said.
An SPX options trader at the Chicago Board Options Exchange said many market participants were surprised by the rally.

"Some of the large houses are usually pretty good at calling direction," he said. "But a lot of them were in selling a lot of calls and buying a lot of puts this morning and it doesn't seem to be working out too good right now."

He said if the market continues to "trudge" higher over the next couple of months, volatility would likely flatten out at elevated levels on the expectation that the market would be poised to correct sharply.
"The expectation that the market's got to fall is just going to keep premium levels up high," the trader said.
Among the biggest trades, an investor did a large spread in the SPX, buying the September 825 puts and selling the June 775 puts about 9,000 times, traders said.
"That's going to have an effect on June volatility versus September," the SPX trader said, explaining that June volatility eased a bit while September volatility moved higher.
At the Merc, the index options trader said most action was from locals, with institutions largely on the sidelines.
